description:
About the book:
There's something profoundly grounding about revisiting a time when music journalism was printed on paper, stacked on newsstands, and kept under pillows for late-night reading. Rock 'n' Beat, Mihajlo Grbevski's debut book, captures that very essence, not just as nostalgia, but as a living document of two decades of conversations with the musicians who shaped, rattled, and redefined the cultural landscape of Macedonia, the Balkans, and beyond.
At 230 pages, Rock 'n' Beat isn't just a collection of interviews‚Äîit's a time capsule. Grbevski, a seasoned music journalist whose byline appeared regularly in outlets like Ekran, Ritam, Vreme, and Nova Makedonija, has curated 50 interviews spanning his nearly 20-year career. The book gathers these dialogues with care, organizing them into four thematic chapters that mirror both the diversity of the music scene and the changing face of regional and global music.

The first section, Rock Spring, pays tribute to Macedonian rock's pioneering voices. Here, Grbevski sits down with musicians who laid the foundation for the country's sonic identity: Vlatko Stefanovski, Garabet Tavitjan, Bodan Arsovski, and Kiril Djaikovski, among others. These interviews are not just about music but about legacy, craft, and the complicated road of building a local scene in a small but culturally rich corner of Europe. Reading these conversations feels like sitting in on private jam sessions where history, technique, and personal struggle collide.
Eternal Rebel, the second chapter, opens the stage to international icons‚Äîartists who often visited Skopje and left a lasting imprint on audiences and journalists alike. Grbevski's interviews with Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols, Ian Gillan of Deep Purple, David Coverdale of Whitesnake, Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top, and jazz guitarist Al Di Meola are among the book's highlights. These conversations manage to avoid the superficial. They offer glimpses into the minds of artists who, despite global fame, reveal doubts, humor, and sometimes, surprising humility.

The traditional annual concert of the Vocal-Instrumental Ensemble Biljana will take place in front of the Church of the Holy Mother of God Perivlepta in Ohrid, on September 5th, 2025 (Friday) at 8:00 PM.

This year, for the thirteenth time, we will come together to enjoy the timeless sounds of the old-town song. Our special guests for this edition are Emilija Koloska and Stefan Petreski.
locationName: Church of the Holy Mother of God Perivlepta
